quoteFirst: The quay at Yarmouth is one of the longest and most spacious of any in the kingdom; but from the shallowness of the entrance of the harbour, there being only fourteen feet of water on the bar at spring tides, the trade of the place is chiefly carried on in small vessels. It is high water in Yarmouth Roads at
quoteLast: , and at Yarmouth Sands at thirty minutes past ten, on the full and change of the moon.
title: The Ports, Harbours, Watering-places and Picturesque Scenery of Great Britain Vol. 1

quoteFirst: In the evening we had a 'phone message, "Stand by to attack Zeppelin," and on looking out, there it was as large as life a few miles out to sea and very high. We rushed up to the aerodrome and got off by
quoteLast: I went straight out to sea after it and got to 6000 feet in 15 minutes, but was never within ten miles of the thing. I wasn't overtaking it at all, but on the contrary it was gaining on me, and after half an hour I lost sight of it.
title:
In the Royal Naval Air Service
Being the war letters of the late Harold Rosher to his family
author: Rosher, Harold, 1893-1916; Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteTime: twenty minutes to nine in the evening

quoteFirst: When Aunt Sarah came down into the great hall at
quoteLast: that evening she found it full of young men and women who had arrived about an hour before, and whom she had kept waiting ten minutes for their dinner. She did not apologize for her late appearance. That was not her custom.
title: The Strand Magazine, Vol. 27, January 1904, No. 157

quoteFirst: Why, with their scufflings and horse-play and noise, it was just a menagerie.  Besides, a concert of amateurs had been smuggled into the program (to precede me,) and their families and friends (say ten per cent of the audience) kept encoring them and they always responded.  So it was
quoteLast: before I got the platform in front of those 2,600 people who had paid a dollar apiece for a chance to go to hell in this fashion.
title: The Entire Project Gutenberg Works of Mark Twain
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: At eight o’clock we passed through the canal and steamed up the lake to Tunis, but it was slow work, for care has to be taken not to stir up the water; so working a ship in this harbour takes time; it was therefore
quoteLast: before I landed, after having taken leave of Colonel Gousset and the other officers.

quoteLast: , and that a clock in the room had stopped at twenty minutes to nine.

quoteFirst: “You may hear the rumour of the alarming and truly awful calamity that has occurred in this city, before you receive this.  I have witnessed it, and shall hold the recollection as long as my memory exists.  About
quoteLast: last evening, I was told the Minster was on fire.  I ran out, immediately, towards it, and stood by it, just as the flames had issued from the top part of the south-west tower, at a height that an engine could not have played upon.
title: Gossip in the First Decade of Victoria's Reign
author: Ashton, John, 1834-1911

quoteFirst: “Come, watch, oblige me by telling us the hour that last struck.” (We will suppose that the time is
quoteLast: .) To the astonishment of all, the watch chimes eight successive strokes, with a clear bell-like tone. “Now the last quarter.” The watch chimes “two” and stops. “You see, sir, that under the mesmeric influence your watch becomes a capital repeater. Let us test its intelligence still further.
title: Modern Magic: A Practical Treatise on the Art of Conjuring
